headline.main: Split With Red Sox Puts Division Title Within the Yankees’ Reach
headline.print_headline: Split With Red Sox Puts Division Title Within the Yankees’ Reach
headline.kicker: Red Sox 5, Yankees 2; Yankees 7, Red Sox 5

docs.lead_paragraph: BOSTON -- The first 161 games were not enough. The American League East title will come down to the final day of the regular season, the Yankees' third game in 24 hours. Maximizing the drama from a captivating season-long race with Tampa Bay, the Yankees, after splitting a doubleheader Saturday with the Red Sox, are tied atop the division with the Rays. Only one scenario -- a victory combined with a Rays loss -- will give the Yankees the division championship and home-field advantage throughout the A.L. playoffs. If the Yankees and Tampa Bay finish in a tie, the Rays will win the title because they won the season series. After beating the Red Sox, 6-5, in 10 innings, the Yankees committed four errors, then blew a two-run lead in the eighth and lost, 7-6, in the second game on a 10th-inning single by Eric Patterson off Ivan Nova at 1:22 a.m.
docs.abstract: New York Yankees defeat Boston Red Sox, 6-5; because Tampa Bay Rays have edge in tiebreaker, Yankees will need victory and Rays loss to win division; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Millar entered this homestand as one of the primary culprits for the Red Sox' woes, and the team knew it would have a hard time improving without more production from Millar, its slumping first baseman. After the Red Sox defeated the Yankees, 9-6, on Sunday night, it appeared that he was making a turnaround. Millar was one of the Red Sox' most disappointing players during the first half, and hope that he could spearhead a second-half revival hung over Fenway Park on Sunday night as he continued to smash the ball all over the park. He was in the midst of a dismal season when the Red Sox returned to town on Wednesday. After hitting 25 home runs and driving in 96 runs last season, Millar had just 5 home runs and 25 runs batted in his first 85 games this season.

headline.print_headline: For Yanks, a Chill in the Air and in the Stands

docs.lead_paragraph: Reid Nichols smacked four hits, including a two-run homer and two doubles, to lead the Boston Red Sox to an 8-2 victory over the California Angels tonight. Bob Stanley pitched six and two-thirds innings of two-hit relief to help the Eastern Division leaders win for the sixth time in the last seven games. California, first in the West, had won three of its four previous games. Ellis Valentine tagged the Boston starter Bruce Hurst for his first homer of the season in the first inning. But a single by Dwight Evans and a triple by Tony Armas tied the game in the bottom of the inning.
